figure.note: Pen and ink drawing: view of Gibraltar
figure.label: Moorish walls

div.ab: This view is taken from a spot near the Governors summer cottage Eeast of the rock. Lleft are seen some walls said to be moorish. High up toward the peak is seen the powder magazine
div.note: MochlinMoclín the right eye & Illorathe shield of Granada Alhama
div.ab:
From Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, p. 95. Casiri gives both Latin and Arabic, but WG probably translated the Arabic (given his pride and the very loose relationship of his translation to the Latin). In the Granada library are poems of Abu Baker Mohamad Ben Abrahim Almari Alcarschi who had This on his Tomb. I translated this so
As God ordains my death foredoom’d must be
Kings, Prophet, Adam all preceeded me
Go Thou prepare who glories in my death
For soon shall Fate require thy latest breath.
Born at Silves 28 miles from S. Maria

From Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, p. 106, including Arabic and biographical detail. Valadata Dau’rdaughter of King Mohamad Almostakphi Billah born at Cordoba wrote verses of which translation. “Aspectus noster vestra vulnerat corda: vester & aspectus nostras ferit genas. Pro Vulnere vulnus: jam pares ergo sumus. Attamen genarum vulnus acerbius semper erit.Our countenance wounds your hearts: and your gaze strikes our cheeks. Wound for wound: now, therefore, we are equal. The wound on the cheeks, however, will always be more severe. لحاظنا تجرحكم في الحشا ولحظكم يجرحنا في الخدودOur looks [women’s looks] hurt you [men] deeply and clearly show on you. However, your looks [men’s looks] barely hurt us [women] and only show on our cheeks. Abdusi a noble of Cordoba in love with her.

Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, p. 107. Some poems end in a letter as [Arabic] whence called Siniat. one of Ebn Badis of Cordova commented by Ahmad Ben Alhagi of Granada. Hegirae 759AH 759 (Anno Hegirae, the Islamic calendar).
Casiri, Bibliotheca, vol. 1, p. 118. Mohamad Abi Baker Altalmasani of Granata
